AI Literacy - Questions & Answers Regarding Article 4 of the AI Act

This document excerpt focuses on the interpretation and implications of Article 4 of the AI Act, specifically concerning the requirement for providers and deployers of AI systems to ensure a sufficient level of AI literacy among their staff and other individuals involved in the operation and use of these systems. Article 4 mandates that these entities must equip their personnel with the necessary skills, knowledge, and understanding to effectively utilize AI systems while also fostering awareness of the associated opportunities and potential risks, including possible harm. The definition of ‚ÄòAI literacy‚Äô as outlined in Article 3(56) of the AI Act is central to this provision, defining it as the ‚Äòskills, knowledge and understanding that allow providers, deployers and aÔ¨Äected persons, taking into account their respective rights and obligations in the context of this Regulation, to make an informed deployment of AI systems, as well as to gain awareness about the opportunities and risks of AI and possible harm it can cause.‚Äô The document clarifies that ‚Äòother persons‚Äô refers to anyone directly involved in the operation or use of AI systems on behalf of the provider or deployer, emphasizing a broad scope encompassing all individuals interacting with the system. This provision is a critical component of the AI Act, designed to mitigate risks and promote responsible AI development and deployment. The document highlights the need for a holistic approach, considering technical expertise, experience, education, training, and the specific context of AI system usage. Ultimately, Article 4 aims to establish a baseline level of understanding among stakeholders, contributing to safer and more ethical AI practices. The focus on ‚Äòaffected persons‚Äô suggests a broader consideration of individuals impacted by the AI system, not just those directly involved in its operation.

Key Concepts:

  • Article 4 of the AI Act mandates AI literacy for providers and deployers of AI systems.
  • AI literacy encompasses skills, knowledge, and understanding related to informed AI system deployment and awareness of associated risks.
  • The scope of Article 4 includes providers, deployers, and ‚Äòother persons‚Äô involved in the operation and use of AI systems.
  • Mandatory AI Governance Structure: The AI Act does not mandate a specific governance structure.
  • AI Literacy Initiative: Organizations have an obligation to ensure AI literacy of their staff.
  • Enforcement Timeline: Enforcement begins on August 3, 2026, while obligations related to AI literacy apply from February 2, 2025.
  • Role of National Authorities: National market surveillance authorities will be responsible for supervising and enforcing the AI Act.
  • Development of AI competencies among teachers
  • Safe and effective use of AI in education
  • Building AI competencies in students and citizens
